body: Yo did you catch my comment on service worker js? It would take someone with your technical capabilities a few hours at most. It will really help you scale bro. A ton of the requests your servers are fielding is data that could be stored in local browser storage and accessed by the service worker. Down the road when you want to impliment infiniscroll you just tie service worker into intersectional observer or whatever you use. People will be shocked by the performance upgrade bro.
body_html: Yo did you catch my comment on service worker js? It would take someone with your technical capabilities a few hours at most. It will really help you scale bro. A ton of the requests your servers are fielding is data that could be stored in local browser storage and accessed by the service worker. Down the road when you want to impliment infiniscroll you just tie service worker into intersectional observer or whatever you use. People will be shocked by the performance upgrade bro.

body:
Tried to move hosting services.

Part 1 - the ruqqus application - went smoothly.

Part 2 - the Ruqqus databases - did not. After a few minutes of bad performance on the new host, I reverted everything back to the first hosting service.

It was the few minutes of bad performance that was lost.
body_html:
Tried to move hosting services.

Part 1 - the ruqqus application - went smoothly.

Part 2 - the Ruqqus databases - did not. After a few minutes of bad performance on the new host, I reverted everything back to the first hosting service.

It was the few minutes of bad performance that was lost.

body: Wish I had more insight for you, have zero experience with the Heroku platform. I went noSQL since my use case was ~1000 max simultaneous users grabbing big chunks of (not always well-structured) data fairly often, rather than the death by a thousand cuts you're suffering from. Sharding seems like a potential answer to your problem but that's a relatively recent development from PostgreSQL from what I understand and I have no idea what kind of support for forked/follower databases your platform has, but I can imagine that a single leader is a bottleneck and a half for this kind of site. Good luck.
body_html: Wish I had more insight for you, have zero experience with the Heroku platform. I went noSQL since my use case was ~1000 max simultaneous users grabbing big chunks of (not always well-structured) data fairly often, rather than the death by a thousand cuts you're suffering from. Sharding seems like a potential answer to your problem but that's a relatively recent development from PostgreSQL from what I understand and I have no idea what kind of support for forked/follower databases your platform has, but I can imagine that a single leader is a bottleneck and a half for this kind of site. Good luck.

parent.body: PostgreSQL. I wasn't able to get the leader-follower configuration set up. Heroku makes this easy, and it looked easy in postgres (change some values in postgres.conf) but it wasn't working, and the single leader db was getting the shit hammered out of it with read queries.
parent.body_html: PostgreSQL. I wasn't able to get the leader-follower configuration set up. Heroku makes this easy, and it looked easy in postgres (change some values in postgres.conf) but it wasn't working, and the single leader db was getting the shit hammered out of it with read queries.

body:
Reads are generally 100x more frequent than writes. And reads also have the potential to ask for convoluted information that requires joins and such. 

Heroku has really good support for leader/follower setups, but I botched it up on Linode and decided to go back to Heroku rather than risk something worse.
body_html:
Reads are generally 100x more frequent than writes. And reads also have the potential to ask for convoluted information that requires joins and such.

Heroku has really good support for leader/follower setups, but I botched it up on Linode and decided to go back to Heroku rather than risk something worse.

parent.body: Wish I had more insight for you, have zero experience with the Heroku platform. I went noSQL since my use case was ~1000 max simultaneous users grabbing big chunks of (not always well-structured) data fairly often, rather than the death by a thousand cuts you're suffering from. Sharding seems like a potential answer to your problem but that's a relatively recent development from PostgreSQL from what I understand and I have no idea what kind of support for forked/follower databases your platform has, but I can imagine that a single leader is a bottleneck and a half for this kind of site. Good luck.
parent.body_html: Wish I had more insight for you, have zero experience with the Heroku platform. I went noSQL since my use case was ~1000 max simultaneous users grabbing big chunks of (not always well-structured) data fairly often, rather than the death by a thousand cuts you're suffering from. Sharding seems like a potential answer to your problem but that's a relatively recent development from PostgreSQL from what I understand and I have no idea what kind of support for forked/follower databases your platform has, but I can imagine that a single leader is a bottleneck and a half for this kind of site. Good luck.
